questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with multiple sexual partners presents with painful genital sores that started two days ago, accompanied by flu-like symptoms, fever, and headache. Examination shows shallow ulcers (as shown in the image) and tender inguinal lymphadenopathy. A swab of the ulcer has been sent for testing. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Herpes simplex virus

 

Explanation:

The scenario of painful genital ulcers (as shown in the image above), flu-like symptoms, tender inguinal lymphadenopathy, and a history of multiple sexual partners is most likely indicative of a Herpes Simplex Virus Type 2 (HSV 2) infection.

 

Genital lesions of HSV

  • Mostly seen in HSV type 2.
  • Bilateral, painful genital vesiculo-ulcerative lesions.

  • Tender inguinal lymphadenopathy.
  • Site: Lesions are mainly seen on,
    • Males: The penis or in the urethra (urethritis).
    • Females: The cervix, vagina, vulva and perineum
  • It is associated with systemic features like fever (flu-like) and malaise.
  • In pregnant females, a cesarean is preferred over normal labour to prevent vertical transmission.

 

Haemophilus ducreyi (Option A) is a gram-negative bacillus that causes painful, non-indurated irregular ulcers on the genitalia (chancroid or soft sore) (which is not vesicular as seen in HSV 2, and there is no association of flu-like symptoms).


Treponema pallidum (Option B) is a spirochete that causes syphilis, resulting in the characteristic painless, relatively avascular, circumscribed, indurated, superficially ulcerated lesion (hard chancre).

Klebsiella granulomatis (Option C) is a gram-negative bacteria that causes a painless papule on the genitalia, which leads to a slowly progressive, auto-inoculable ulcer known as donovanosis or granuloma inguinale.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department with sudden confusion, fever, and seizures over the past 24 hours. Her partner reports memory loss and difficulty recognising faces. Examination reveals a fever of 102°F, disorientation, and mild aphasia. PCR is positive for HSV. Which feature is not associated with the causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Mollaret meningitis

Explanation:

  • The scenario presenting with seizures, aphasia, disorientation, confusion, fever, and positive PCR testing for HSV indicates a diagnosis of herpes simplex virus encephalitis caused by HSV-1.
  • Mollaret meningitis is recurrent aseptic meningitis associated with HSV-2, not HSV-1.

Clinical manifestations of Herpes simplex virus

  • Cutaneous:
    • Site:
      • Face (cheeks, chin, around the mouth or on the forehead)
      • Buttocks (infants as napkin rash)
    • 'Fever blister' or herpes febrile or cold sores (viral reactivation in febrile patients)
    • Herpetic whitlow: Occupational variety seen in doctors, dentists, and nurses.
    • Eczema herpeticum: Generalised crops of vesicles appear in the affected area with widespread ulceration, as seen in children with eczema.
    • Herpes gladiatorum (Wrestler’s herpes): In athletes who play skin-to-skin contact sports like wrestlers.
    • Herpes multiforme (red, raised, target-like lesions on skin)

 

  • Mucosal
    • Site: Buccal mucosa (most common)
    • Gingivostomatitis and pharyngitis (primary infection) (Option A)
    • Recurrent herpes labialis (Option B)
  • Ophthalmic
    • Dendritic corneal ulcers (Option D)
    • Corneal blindness and conjunctivitis are also observed
    • Chorioretinitis and acute necrotising retinitis are rare.
  • Nervous system
    • Encephalitis (HSV Encephalitis)
      • Caused by HSV-1
      • Most common cause of sporadic acute viral encephalitis
      • Affected site: Temporal lobe
    • Meningitis
      • Most commonly caused by HSV-2
      • Mollaret meningitis (recurrent lymphocytic meningitis) (Option C)
      • HSV can result in Bell's palsy.
  • Visceral
    • Symptoms like dysphagia, substernal pain and weight loss.
    • Tracheobronchitis and pneumonitis (lung involvement)
  • Genital infections
    • Mostly seen in HSV type 2
    • Bilateral, painful genital vesiculo-ulcerative lesions
    • Tender inguinal lymphadenopathy
    • Site: Lesions are mainly seen on,
      • Male: The penis or in the urethra (urethritis).
      • Female: The cervix, vagina, vulva and perineum.
  • Congenital
    • If a pregnant woman has genital lesions during labour, the risk of infection can be mitigated by performing a cesarean section.
    • Neonatal herpes: A disseminated disease involving multiple organs, with or without encephalitis. The mortality rate is high, and survivors may have neurological impairments.
    • Transplacental infections leading to congenital malformations are rare.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant presents with a 1-week history of fever, irritability, decreased appetite, and lethargy. Examination reveals high temperature, moderate hepatomegaly, and purpura/petechiae on the trunk and extremities. CBC shows thrombocytopenia and leukopenia. ELISA detects antibodies for antigen PP65. What is the cause of the condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) HHV 5

 

Explanation:

The presentation suggests cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection, caused by Human Herpesvirus 5 (HHV-5), indicated by fever, hepatomegaly, petechiae/purpura, thrombocytopenia, leukopenia, and the detection of antibodies to the specific CMV antigen PP65 via ELISA.

 

CMV infection

Modes of transmission
  • Oral route, respiratory & body secretions (most common)
  • Vertical transmission
  • Sexual transmission
  • Organ transplantation
  • Blood transfusion

Host cells
  • Salivary gland
  • Kidney

Clinical features

Congenital infection
  • Most common intrauterine infection with congenital defects.
  • Common presentation:
    • Petechiae
    • Hepatosplenomegaly
    • Jaundice
  • Less common presentation:
    • Microcephaly
    • Cerebral calcifications
    • Intrauterine growth retardation
    • Prematurity
  • Other defects: Sensorineural hearing loss.

Perinatal infection
  • Commonly asymptomatic.
  • Occasionally, premature infants present with interstitial pneumonitis.

Immunocompromised
  • Seen in AIDS, HIV, organ transplant patients and cancer patients undergoing chemo
  • Presentations in AIDS and HIV
    • CMV chorioretinitis
    • Progressive dementia,
    • Cranial nerve defects,
  • Presentations in Organ transplant
    • Bilateral interstitial pneumonia
    • Febrile leukopenia
    • Obliterative bronchiolitis
    • Graft atherosclerosis
    • Rejection of renal allografts.

Immunocompetent
  • Usually, it occurs following a blood transfusion.
  • It presents similar to infectious mononucleosis, but heterophile antibody tests would be negative.

Investigations

Peripheral smear

Owl’s eye appearance of inclusion bodies

Virus isolation

It is done by

  • Human fibroblast cell line culture
  • Shell vial culture

Antigen detected

PP65

Antibody detection

It is done by ELISA, and the antibodies detected are

  • CMV IgM antibodies
  • CMV IgG antibodies
  • Against PP150 and PP65,
  • Against the PP52

PCR
  • Used in detecting CMV DNA
  • Quantitative nucleic acid testing (QNAT) by PCR is the most sensitive and specific testing.

Treatment
  • Ganciclovir (Drug of choice)
  • Foscarnet (in Ganciclovir resistance)
  • CMV immunoglobulins and Ganciclovir are given to bone marrow transplant patients.

 

HHV 1 (Option A) is Herpes simplex virus 1, which causes oral herpes (cold sores) and can commonly lead to encephalitis or herpes keratitis.

  • It is not typically associated with the systemic symptoms, hepatomegaly, thrombocytopenia, or the presence of the PP65 antigen seen in the infant's case.

 

HHV 2 (Option B), also known as Herpes simplex virus 2, primarily causes genital herpes.

  • While it can cause severe disease in newborns, especially during delivery (neonatal herpes), it does not typically present with the systemic symptoms described in this infant's presentation.
  • Like HHV 1, it is not associated with the PP65 antigen.

 

HHV 4 (Option C) is the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), primarily associated with infectious mononucleosis and certain lymphoproliferative disorders.

  • It does not show antibodies against the PP65 antigen.

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman in her second trimester reports mild flu-like symptoms and mild lymphadenopathy during a routine check-up. An ultrasound shows signs of intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR). She is diagnosed with the infection caused by the largest member of the human herpesviridae (HHV) family. Which subfamily does it belong to?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Betaherpesviruses

 

Explanation:

  • The infection described is likely caused by cytomegalovirus (CMV), a member of the Betaherpesvirinae subfamily of the Herpesviridae family.
  • CMV is the largest human herpesvirus and can cause congenital infection, leading to intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR) and other fetal complications.
  • It often presents with mild, flu-like symptoms and lymphadenopathy in pregnant individuals.

 

General Properties of Herpesviridae:

  • Double-stranded DNA viruses (enveloped)
  • Icosahedral symmetry
  • eplication site: Host cell nucleus
  • Size: 150-200 nm (2nd largest virus)
  • Largest virus: Pox virus (300nm)
  • Smallest virus: Parvovirus (20nm)
  • Characteristics of infection:
    • Latent infection (ability to persist within the infected host)
    • Periodic reactivation
  • Classification

Subfamily

questions.text: A 25-year-old man visits urgent care with painful lip sores and a fever, which began after a recent cold and increased work stress. Examination reveals vesicular lesions around his lips (as shown below) and swollen lymph nodes in his neck, suggesting infection by an enveloped double-stranded DNA virus. Which feature is associated with this organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Latency occurs in trigeminal ganglion

 

Explanation:

The scenario, marked by orofacial lesions, lymphadenopathy, a recent cold, and work-related stress, indicates an infection with Herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1), an enveloped, double-stranded DNA virus that establishes latency in the trigeminal ganglion.

 

Aspects

Herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV 1)

Herpes simplex virus type 2 (HSV 2)

Transmission

Mucosal membrane or abraded skin

Sexual or vertical (mother to baby) (Option A)

Site of latency

Trigeminal ganglia (Option C)

Sacral ganglia

Age group

Children

Adults (Option D)

Clinical features

  • Skin lesions above the waist (oral lesions like gingivostomatitis and labialis)
  • Encephalitis
  • Meningitis
  • Skin lesions below the waist (mainly genital lesions) - Painful
  • Neonatal herpes (vertical transmission) (Option B)

Growth on chick embryo fibroblasts

Poor growth

Good growth

(larger pox resembling variola)

Neurovirulence

Less

More

Less

More

questions.text: A 24-year-old male wrestler presents with a painful rash on his forehead and neck, initially small red bumps that developed into fluid-filled blisters (shown in the image). He reports fever and malaise for the past few days. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Herpes gladiatorum

 

Explanation:

The scenario describes a wrestler with painful fluid-filled blisters and flu-like symptoms, which is diagnosed as Herpes gladiatorum, also known as Wrestler’s Herpes.

 

Herpes gladiatorum:

  • A cutaneous lesion observed in infections caused by the Herpes simplex virus.
  • Transmission: Contact sports, like wrestling, due to skin-to-skin contact in athletes.
  • Feature: Painful, fluid-filled blisters on the skin, accompanied by symptoms like fever and malaise.
  • Treatment: Antiviral medications
  • Prevention: Good hygiene practices during sports.

 

Herpetic whitlow (Option A) is another type of cutaneous lesion associated with HSV infection.

  • It commonly occurs on the fingers of doctors and healthcare workers who have been exposed to infected patients.

Herpes zoster (Option C), or shingles, is caused by the Varicella zoster virus (HHV 3).

  • It occurs when the virus reactivates and travels along sensory nerves, producing zoster lesions in the affected skin area, often accompanied by neuritic pain.

Eczema herpeticum (Option D) is another cutaneous lesion linked to HSV infection.

  • It presents as generalised clusters of vesicles on the affected area, often accompanied by widespread ulceration, and is typically seen in children with eczema.

questions.text:
Match the following herpes virus with its corresponding microscopic findings.

 


	
		
			
			1. Herpes Simplex Virus
			
			
			A. 

			
			
		
		
			
			2. Epstein Barr Virus
			
			
			B.

			
			
		
		
			
			3. Cytomegalovirus
			
			
			C.

			
			
		
		
			
			4. Human herpes virus type 8
			
			
			D.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 1-C, 2-D, 3-B, 4-A

 

Explanation:

 

Microscopic features of the herpes virus:

Herpes simplex virus

  • Tzanck smear: Multinucleated giant cells with faceted nuclei and homogeneously stained 'ground-glass' chromatin (Tzanck cells).
  • Formation of Lipschutz bodies (Cowdry type A).

EBV (Epstein Barr virus)

  • Downey cells: Atypical lymphocytes (large, vacuolated) are observed.
  • Ballerina skirt appearance.

CMV (Cytomegalovirus)

  • The presence of inclusion bodies gives the characteristic “Owl-eye appearance”.

HHV 8 (human herpes virus type 8)

  • Castleman disease: Onion skinning of lymphocytes and blood vessels, giving the appearance of “Lollipop follicles”.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman at 20 weeks gestation reports a mild rash, fever, and flu-like symptoms after exposure to a child with a rash. Ultrasound shows cicatricial lesions, limb hypoplasia, microcephaly, and intrauterine growth restriction. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Congenital varicella syndrome

 

Explanation:

  • The scenario describes a pregnant woman at 20 weeks of gestation with flu-like symptoms, fever, and a rash, while the fetus shows limb hypoplasia, microcephaly, and cicatricial lesions, indicating a diagnosis of Congenital (or fetal) Varicella Syndrome.

 

Congenital Varicella Syndrome: If a pregnant woman contracts the varicella-zoster virus during the first 20 weeks of gestation, the virus may be transmitted to the fetus through the placenta, leading to congenital (or fetal) varicella syndrome.

  • Clinical features (fetus):
    • Cicatricial skin lesion
    • Limb hypoplasia
    • Microcephaly
    • Cortical atrophy
    • Chorioretinitis
    • Some babies may carry latent infection without exhibiting any defects.

Congenital rubella syndrome (Option A) occurs when a mother transmits rubella to her fetus, resulting in miscarriage or classic triad of cataract, patent ductus arteriosus and sensorineural hearing loss and also various complications such as hepatosplenomegaly, thrombocytopenic purpura, myocarditis, and bone lesions.

Congenital toxoplasmosis (Option C) occurs when non-immune mothers are infected with Toxoplasma gondii during pregnancy.

  • This can lead to stillbirths, chorioretinitis, intracranial calcifications, psychomotor disturbances, and conditions such as hydrocephaly or microcephaly.
  • The classic triad of neurological findings consists of chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and intracranial calcifications.

Congenital CMV infection (Option D) results from a cytomegalovirus infection during pregnancy and can lead to fetal death or cytomegalic inclusion disease in newborns, often characterised by hepatosplenomegaly, jaundice, thrombocytopenic purpura, hemolytic anaemia, and a "blueberry muffin rash" with purplish-blue spots due to extramedullary hematopoiesis, where blood cell production occurs outside the bone marrow.

  • Survivors may experience mental retardation and developmental delays.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a history of diabetes presents with a painful rash on the right side of his torso. He reports that the pain began as a burning sensation a few days ago, and he has since developed red, blistering, and tender lesions, as shown below. What is the most common complication of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Postherpetic neuralgia

Explanation:

  • The scenario depicts a diabetic (poor immunity) male with a painful, blistering rash on one side of his torso, diagnosed as Herpes Zoster (Shingles).
  • The most common complication associated with this condition is postherpetic neuralgia.
  • It occurs in individuals who previously had chickenpox, allowing the virus to remain latent in the sensory ganglia and reactivate during immunocompromised states, such as old age, diabetes, or HIV.
  • Complications
    • Postherpetic neuralgia (Option A): Pain and paresthesia at the affected site
    • Zoster ophthalmicus (Option B): The reactivation of the virus in the trigeminal ganglion is marked by symptoms like pain, blisters, fever, and malaise, and it can also lead to the formation of dendritic corneal ulcers.
    • Ramsay Hunt syndrome (Option D)
      • Reactivation of the virus involving the geniculate ganglion of the facial nerve can cause lesions to erupt on the tympanic membrane and the external auditory canal (otalgia).
      • This condition may also present with symptoms such as facial palsy, Bell's palsy, and loss of taste in the anterior 2/3rd of the tongue.
      • Other complications like meningoencephalitis (Option C) and lower motor neuron paralysis might also occur

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents with severe fatigue, a sore throat, and swollen lymph nodes for the past week, noting a similar illness in her partner. Examination shows low-grade fever, mild hepatosplenomegaly, and cervical lymphadenopathy. A complete blood count indicates absolute lymphocytosis with atypical lymphocytes. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Glandular fever

 

Explanation:

The clinical presentation suggests an Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) or HHV 4 (human herpes virus type 4) infection, diagnosed as Infectious Mononucleosis (also known as Kissing Disease or Glandular Fever).

 

Epstein-Barr virus (EBV):

  • Route of infection: Close contact, kissing, sexual intercourse, blood transfusion, bone marrow transplant.
  • Site of latency: B cells
  • Family: Herpesviridae (gamma (γ) or gammaherpesviruses)
  • Clinical conditions:
    • Infectious mononucleosis
    • EBV-associated malignancies: Burkitt's lymphoma, lymphomas in immunodeficient (AIDS and transplant recipients), nasopharyngeal carcinoma.
  • Pathogenesis: Polyclonal B cell activation
  • Infectious mononucleosis (Kissing disease or Glandular fever)
    • Incubation period: 4-8 weeks
    • Clinical features: Splenomegaly, hepatitis, encephalitis, fever, sore throat, lymphadenopathy, arthralgia, lethargy.
    • Microscopy:
      • Downey cells: Atypical lymphocytes (large, vacuolated) are observed.
      • Appearance: Ballerina skirt appearance.

Influenza (Option A), commonly known as the flu, is a contagious respiratory illness caused by influenza viruses.

  • It can affect people of all ages and is characterised by sudden onset of fever, body aches, and respiratory symptoms (hepatosplenomegaly and atypical lymphocytes are not characteristic of influenza).

Toxoplasmosis (Option B) is an infection caused by the parasite Toxoplasma gondii.

  • It is one of the most prevalent parasitic infections in humans and presents with symptoms such as mild flu-like signs (fever, muscle aches), swollen lymph nodes, fatigue, and headaches (without atypical lymphocytes).

CMV (Cytomegalovirus) infection (Option C) is often asymptomatic; however, in some cases, it can present with flu-like symptoms such as fever, fatigue, and sore throat.

  • Microscopy reveals the characteristic "owl-eye" appearance of the infected cells.

questions.text: A 21-year-old male presents with extreme fatigue, a severe sore throat, and swollen lymph nodes for two weeks, with similar recent symptoms in his partner. Examination reveals hepatosplenomegaly and cervical lymphadenopathy, and lab results showed a high percentage of atypical lymphocytes. All the following malignancies are associated with it except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Angiosarcoma

 

Explanation:

  • The patient's presentation is consistent with infectious mononucleosis (kissing disease or glandular fever), likely caused by Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV).
  • Angiosarcoma is a rare malignancy of endothelial cells and is not associated with EBV infection.

 

Malignancies associated with EBV:

Types of malignancy

Examples

Carcinoma

  • Gastric carcinoma (most common) (Option C)
  • Nasopharyngeal carcinoma (Option D)

Lymphoma

  • Hodgkin’s lymphoma (most common lymphocyte depletion and mixed cellularity)
  • Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma
    • Burkitt’s lymphoma (Option B)
    • DLBCL (diffuse large B cell lymphoma)
    • Post-transplant lymphoma
    • T or NK cell lymphoma

Sarcoma

  • Leiomyosarcoma

questions.text: A 22-year-old male college student comes in with a 1-week history of fever, significant fatigue, sore throat, and swollen cervical lymph nodes. Examination shows elevated temperature, bilateral tender lymphadenopathy, and tonsillar enlargement with exudate. His CBC reveals leukocytosis with atypical lymphocytes. How does the heterophile agglutination test aid in diagnosing his condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Antibodies react with sheep RBC

 

Explanation:

  • The heterophile agglutination (Paul-Bunnell test) test, also known as the Monospot test, is used to diagnose infectious mononucleosis, typically caused by Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV).
  • It detects heterophile antibodies that react with antigens on non-human red blood cells, such as sheep or horse RBCs.

 

Investigations for EBV

Peripheral smear
  • Initially, leukopenia is noted, often followed by leukocytosis as the condition progresses.
  • The presence of atypical mononuclear cells (derived from cytotoxic T cells) exhibits basophilic vacuolated cytoplasm and kidney-shaped nuclei (Downey cells).
  • Ballerina skirt appearance: Characteristic morphology where atypical lymphocytes have cytoplasm that extends and flares, resembling a ballerina’s skirt.

Serology

Heterophile antibody test (Non-specific antibody test)
  • Paul-Bunnell test: Heterophile antibodies react with Sheep RBC.
  • Monospot test: Heterophile antibodies react with Horse RBC.

Specific antibody test (ELISA or Immunofluorescence)
  • lgM antibody against Viral Capsid antigen (earliest antigen) (Option C).
  • Antibody against the EB nuclear antigen (EBNA) (Option B).
  • Antibodies against early antigens (Option A).

Culture

For Virus isolation

Not commonly used.

Other tests
  • PCR
  • Nucleic acid hybridisation test (Most sensitive & specific)

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy has been brought to the clinic with a painful blistering rash around his mouth for the past three days, accompanied by a low-grade fever and irritability. Examination reveals lesions as below and cervical lymphadenopathy. The mother mentions a history of recurrent cold sores. What is the most appropriate management for this child?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Acyclovir

 

Explanation:

  • The child's presentation of a painful blistering rash around the mouth, low-grade fever, irritability, and a history of recurrent cold sores suggests an outbreak of Herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection.
  • Acyclovir is the first-line antiviral treatment for herpes simplex virus infections, including oral herpes in children.
  • It is ineffective against CMV because it targets thymidine kinase, an enzyme in herpes simplex virus (HSV) and varicella-zoster virus (VZV), but it is absent in CMV.
  • Valacyclovir and Famciclovir are also effective for managing HSV 1 and 2.
  • Foscarnet is used in conditions that are resistant to the above antivirals.

 

Valganciclovir (Option A) is a prodrug of Ganciclovir.

  • It is mostly used to manage CMV, especially in the case of CMV retinitis.

 

Ganciclovir (Option B) is the drug of choice to manage CMV and is also used to manage EBV; in case of resistance, Foscarnet can be used.

 

Cidofovir (Option C) can be used to manage both CMV and HSV infections. It is effective against many acyclovir-resistant HSV and ganciclovir-resistant CMV cases.

  • However, it is nephrotoxic, so it should be used under caution.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with a sudden high fever for 3 days, followed by a rose-coloured maculopapular rash that starts on the trunk and spreads to the face and extremities. The child is well-hydrated and active. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the diagnosis of this condition?

choices.text: HHV-6 shows limited antigenic cross-reactivity with HHV-7.
HHV-6 can cause symptoms similar to infectious mononucleosis.
HHV 6 and 7 both bind to T- cells.
HHV-6 causes the above condition, and HHV-7 is not related to it.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) HHV-6 causes the above condition, and HHV-7 is not related to it.

 

Explanation:

  • The child's sudden high fever, followed by a rose-coloured maculopapular rash, indicates roseola infantum, primarily caused by human herpesvirus 6 (HHV-6).
  • While HHV-6 causes the condition, HHV-7 is related and can cause similar illnesses.
  • HHV-6 shows some antigenic cross-reactivity with HHV-7, and both bind to T-cells via CD46 (Options A and C).
  • HHV-6 has 2 variants, i.e. A and B.
  • Both HHV 6 & 7 spreads through saliva.

Conditions caused

HHV 6
  • In children: Sixth disease/ Roseola/ Exanthem Subitum (sudden high fever followed by a distinctive rash)
  • In adults: Infectious mononucleosis-like symptoms and focal encephalitis (Option B)
  • In Immunodeficient - Pneumonia and Disseminated disease.

HHV 7

Causes Sixth disease/ Roseola/ Exanthem Subitum in children

questions.text: A 35-year-old man with HIV presents with fever, weight loss, and reddish-purple raised skin lesions. A biopsy shows spindle-shaped cells with mixed inflammatory infiltrate, and serological testing reveals antibodies to Human Herpesvirus 8. Which of the following statements regarding HHV 8 is false?

choices.text: HHV 8 can cause primary effusion lymphoma
HHV 8 does not spread through oral secretions

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) HHV 8 does not spread through oral secretions

 

Explanation:

HHV-8 is found in oral secretions and can spread through saliva (the most common route of transmission). This can also be transmitted through

  • Sexual contact
  • Vertical transmission
  • Blood transfusion
  • Organ transplants

 

HHV 8

Investigations
  • PCR
  • Serological tests: Indirect immunofluorescence, Western blot and ELISA.

Clinical conditions
  • Kaposi sarcoma: (Option B)
    • Commonly affected sites are lower limbs, followed by lymph nodes.
    • It commonly affects the immunocompromised people.
  • Primary effusion lymphoma (Option A)
  • Castleman's disease: (Option C)
    • It is a rare lymphoproliferative disorder characterised by the abnormal growth of lymphoid tissue.
    • Lollipop follicles are a distinctive histological feature seen in lymphoid tissue in this condition.
